title: Lavender Tallow Balm: The Weird Jar That Fixed My Winter Face
body:
Okay so it’s February. It’s dark at like 4 PM. My face feels like it’s made of old paper. You know that feeling? Tight. A little itchy. Just… unhappy. I was scrolling on my phone one night, probably watching a baking video I’d never actually bake, and my knuckles were so dry they looked cracked. I’d tried the lotions. The fancy stuff in the blue bottle that costs as much as a decent dinner. It’d work for an hour. Then back to paper-face.

Anyway. I kept seeing this beef tallow skincare stuff. Tallow. Like… cow fat. For your face. I mean, come on. It sounded like something my great-grandma would have used before they invented, you know, *things*. But the people talking about it seemed normal. Not weird. So I was curious. Skeptical, but curious. I found this little Etsy shop, one of those ones with nice pictures and a short story about grass-fed cows in France. I figured, what’s the worst that could happen? I ordered the **Whipped Tallow Balm** in lavender. A **scented tallow balm** for my skeptical, papery face.

It arrived on a Tuesday. I think it was Tuesday. It was cold. The jar was smaller than I pictured, which is always the way. Simple glass jar. I was sitting on my couch, wearing these socks with holes in the heels, and I opened it.

## What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Smells Like

First thought: Oh. That’s not what I expected.

It doesn’t smell like a candle. Or like those super sweet body washes. It’s not a “calming, sleep-promoting, anxiety relief” scent in a fake way. It just smells like… lavender. But the real plant. Like if you crushed the purple flowers in your hand, a little earthy and green underneath. Not perfume-y. It’s quiet. My apartment smelled like my old neighbor’s garden for a second. The one who grew herbs. It was a good smell. A real smell. It didn’t scream LAVENDER. It just was.

The balm itself looked like soft butter. Whipped beef tallow, they call it. I poked it with my finger. Cold and thick. I got a little blob and rubbed it between my palms. It melted fast. Like, immediately. Went from this solid little scoop to this oily-feeling… but not greasy? I don’t know how to describe it. It just disappeared into my skin. My hands felt… normal. Not slippery. Not filmy. Just my hands, but not thirsty anymore.

I put some on my face that night. After I washed it. I was still half-convinced I’d wake up looking like I’d slept in a frying pan.

## Why Putting Beef Fat on My Face Makes Sense Now

So the whole tallow thing. I looked it up after, because putting beef fat on your face requires some mental gymnastics. Turns out beef tallow—this specific grass-fed, whipped stuff—is weirdly similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So it’s like giving your skin back what it already knows, instead of some lab-made chemical it has to figure out. It just… sinks in. Deep. It doesn’t sit on top like a plastic wrap.

I started using the **lavender tallow balm** every night. It became the thing I did after brushing my teeth. A little ritual. The smell is the best part, honestly. It’s not about “anxiety relief.” It’s just a signal. My brain goes, “Oh, that smell. Day is over. We are done.” I’d put it on my cheeks, my forehead, this stubborn dry patch by my eyebrow. My lips too, because why not. It’s just **natural lavender skincare** that doesn’t have a million ingredients.

My routine got stupid simple. Wash face. Maybe splash with water in the morning. Tallow balm at night. That’s it. I stopped using the seven other bottles on my shelf. They just sat there, looking expensive and useless.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

The change wasn’t overnight. But after maybe a week and a half, I touched my face while I was working and I stopped. It felt different. Not oily. Not dry. Just… even. The tight papery feeling was gone. The little flaky bits around my nose? Gone. My knuckles stopped looking like a desert map.

Here’s the weird human detail: I was at the grocery store, in the freezer aisle, and I caught my reflection in the glass door. And I thought, “Huh. My skin looks… calm.” Not “glowing.” Not “radiant.” Just calm. Like it wasn’t mad at me anymore. It was just existing peacefully. That’s the best way I can put it. The **lavender tallow balm** just made everything chill out. My skin and my brain, because that smell is so genuinely nice.

I used it on a patch of what was probably psoriasis on my elbow, too. Just slathered it on for a few nights. It didn’t magically vanish, but the itching stopped. The skin got softer. Less angry-looking. It just helped. I got my mom a jar for her chapped winter hands. She called me and was like, “What is this witchcraft? It smells like my mother’s linen closet.” High praise.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

I’m on my second jar now. The first one lasted forever, you need so little. I got it from that same Etsy shop, the one with the French grass-fed cows. It’s just a simple, good thing. It’s not magic. It’s not a miracle cream. It’s just a really good, basic thing that works better than the complicated, expensive things.

It’s winter. My face isn’t fighting me. That’s all I wanted. The lavender scent just makes it a nice moment instead of a chore. I look forward to it. That’s the truth. I’ll be watching TV, and I’ll remember I get to put that balm on, and it’s a small, good thing in a dark, cold month.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult, feeling tight or dry or just… beige, this might be worth a shot. The whole beef tallow thing sounds strange until you try it. Then it just makes sense.

---

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. The science-y reason is that it’s similar to our skin’s own oils, so it absorbs deep instead of sitting on top. It’s like giving your skin food it actually recognizes. My face just drinks it up.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. And I can get clogged pores easy. This stuff melts right in. It’s not greasy. It’s more like it just… vanishes and leaves your skin hydrated. Doesn’t feel heavy at all.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Real lavender. Not candy or perfume. Like the actual plant from a garden, with a tiny bit of something green and earthy underneath. It’s gentle. Not overpowering. It just smells like a quiet, calm evening.
